facts.text: This is a petition under article 32 of Constitution and raises the same question on the merits as in the connected summons case.
Number question arises about the breach of a fundamental right.

At a very early stage Mr. G applied to the Registrar and also to the Prothonotary for a copy of the order of the Chief Justice constituting the Tribunal. He was told by the Prothonotary that the order was oral.
Mr. G put in two written statements before the Tribunal and did not challenge this statement of fact in either. He contented himself with saying that the order was not judicial and so was not valid.
He took up the same attitude in the High Court.

The record clearly shows that when it came to the notice of this Court it was decided to refer this case to the Bar Council under section 10(2) and accordingly a Tribunal was appointed under section 11(1) by the learned Chief Justice of this Court.
In his petition to this Court he did not challenge this statement of fact but again confined his attack to the question of the validity of the order.

The letter No. G-1003 dated 29th April, 1953, of the Prothonotary to the Registrar and the letter No. E. 41-09/53 dated the 1st May, 1953, of the Registrar to the Bar Council office copies of which were retained on the files are a sufficient record of the making of the order.
Mr. G was supplied with copies of these letters and so was aware of the fact that orders had been issued.
The originals of the High Court's office files show that the names of the three members of the Tribunal are in the Chief Justice's handwriting with his initials underneath.

legal_issues.text: Whether the proceedings before the Tribunal were ultra vires because there was no proper order of appointment, specifically whether an oral order is sufficient.
Whether there was no complaint to the High Court and so it had no jurisdiction to refer the matter to the Tribunal.
Jurisdiction of the Bar Council Tribunal and that of the Bombay High Court.

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceedings before the Tribunal were ultra vires because there was no proper order of appointment; the order was oral and not judicial so not valid.
There was no complaint to the High Court and so it had no jurisdiction to refer the matter to the Tribunal.

respondent_arguments.text: The record clearly shows that when it came to the notice of this Court it was decided to refer this case to the Bar Council under section 10(2) and accordingly a Tribunal was appointed under section 11(1) by the learned Chief Justice of this Court.
The High Court can refer a matter of this kind of its own motion under section 10(2) of the Bar Councils Act.

court_reasoning.text: The fact that an oral order was made was not challenged by Mr. G in written statements before Tribunal, in High Court, or in petition to Supreme Court; cannot allow Mr. G to go behind that.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fact of oral order not disputed.

court_reasoning.text: Bar Councils Act does not lay down any procedure; section 10(2) allows High Court to refer of its own motion; section 11(2) says Tribunal shall consist of not less than three members appointed by Chief Justice. Necessary that there should be some record but order itself need not be written; can be oral order given to proper officer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Oral order sufficient if recorded appropriately.

court_reasoning.text: Letters dated 29th April 1953 and 1st May 1953 are sufficient record; Mr. G supplied copies; Chief Justice's handwriting on files with initials is additional record.
This ignores the fact that the High Court can refer a matter of this kind of its own motion under section 10(2) of the Bar Councils Act.

holdings.text: An order recorded in the manner set out above is sufficient for the purposes of section 10(2) and 11(2) of the Bar Councils Act and the Tribunal was validly appointed.
High Court had jurisdiction to refer the matter to the Tribunal of its own motion under section 10(2).

statutes_cited.name: Bar Councils Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs referral to Tribunal by High Court and appointment of Tribunal; oral order with record sufficient

outcome.summary: Court rejected Mr. G's objections on jurisdiction, holding that the Tribunal was validly appointed via oral order with sufficient record and that High Court could refer suo motu under section 10(2); merits dealt with in connected case.

key_quotes.text: We hold that an order recorded in the manner set out above is sufficient for the purposes of section 10(2) and 11(2) of the Bar Councils Act and hold that the Tribunal was validity appointed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on validity of oral order

key_quotes.text: It is evident from all this that the fact that an oral order was made was number challenged. We cannot allow Mr. G to go behind that.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects challenge based on non-dispute of fact

key_quotes.text: the High Court can refer a matter of this kind of its own motion under section 10(2) of the Bar Councils Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms High Court's suo motu power
